findings: The feature consistently shows sharp, high-amplitude activation peaks at intergenic boundaries, particularly between divergently transcribed genes or near regulatory regions. These peaks often appear at the interface between genes with regulatory functions (transcriptional regulators, two-component systems) and metabolic or transport genes. The activation pattern appears in diverse bacterial phyla (Proteobacteria, Firmicutes) suggesting a conserved genomic element. In multiple examples, the feature activates near histidine kinases, response regulators, or transcriptional regulators (LysR, TetR families).
conclusion: This feature appears to detect promoter regions or transcriptional start sites, particularly for divergently transcribed genes, representing a biologically meaningful pattern related to gene regulation.
title: Divergent promoter/regulatory region detector
description: This feature detects intergenic regions that likely contain divergent promoters or transcription factor binding sites. It consistently activates at sharp, specific positions between divergently oriented genes, particularly when one gene has regulatory functions (histidine kinases, response regulators, transcription factors). The spikes occur precisely at locations where transcriptional regulation machinery would bind, suggesting the feature recognizes sequence motifs associated with bacterial promoters or regulatory elements. The pattern is highly consistent across diverse bacterial phyla, indicating it detects a fundamental regulatory element in prokaryotic genomes. This feature may represent binding sites for RNA polymerase or global transcription factors that control gene expression at divergently transcribed loci.
